item.title: Racial Divide Seen in Response to Ferguson Unrest, Poll Finds
item.description: A New York Times/CBS News poll found that white Americans are more supportive of Gov. Jay Nixon’s approach to the violence in Missouri than blacks.
item.dc:creator: By MARJORIE CONNELLY

item.title: Ex-Governor to Return to Stand in Virginia Corruption Trial
item.description: Lawyers for Bob McDonnell have promised to detail the marital woes that they say would have prevented the former first couple from any criminal conspiracy.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN WEISMAN and JENNIFER STEINHAUER

item.title: City Room: New York Today: The Easiest, Hardest Month
item.description: What you need to know in New York for Thursday: joys and woes of August, unsettled weather, and parking tickets delivered by email.
item.dc:creator: By ANNIE CORREAL and ANDY NEWMAN
item.media:credit: Ozier Muhammad/The New York Times; Christopher Gregory/The New York Times; Emon Hassan/The New York Times; Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times.

item.title: Aid Group: US Doctor Who Had Ebola Has Recovered
item.description: At least one of the two American aid workers who were infected with the deadly Ebola virus in Africa has recovered and was to be discharged Thursday from an Atlanta hospital, a spokeswoman for the aid group he was working for said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Indonesian Police Fire Tear Gas at Poll Protesters
item.description: Supporters of the losing Indonesian presidential candidate Prabowo Subianto clashed with the police Thursday as the country’s top judges began reading a verdict on his petition to overturn the election results.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: City Room: Vandalism at the Whitney Museum of Art
item.description: A man splashed a red substance on a blank gallery wall where the Jeff Koons retrospective is on display.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: In Ferguson, Scrutiny on Police Is Growing
item.description: Two new lawsuits were filed against the department on Tuesday over the 2011 death of a man whom the police tried to subdue with a Taser gun.

item.title: Israeli Strike in Gaza Strip Kills 3 Top Hamas Commanders
item.description: The strike early Thursday was the most significant blow to the armed wing of Hamas’s leadership since Israel’s Gaza operation began six weeks ago.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and FARES AKRAM

item.title: Lens Blog: Photographing Both Sides in Ukraine
item.description: “Sometimes you accumulate too many sad moments,” said Mauricio Lima, who has been on assignment for The Times in eastern Ukraine.
item.category: The New York Times Lens Blog
item.dc:creator: By MAURICIO LIMA
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents collected water underneath a bridge as several explosions could be heard in central Luhansk. Aug. 14, 2014.

item.title: A Night of Relatively Calm Protests in Ferguson
item.description: There were no real confrontations in the Missouri town overnight, although tensions grew when two protesters turned out in support of the police officer who killed Michael Brown.
item.dc:creator: By JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN and MOSI SECRET

item.title: Analysis: Mo’ne Davis’s Little League World Series Run Draws Appreciation
item.description: Mo’ne Davis and her Philadelphia team lost to Las Vegas, 8-1, at the Little League World Series, but she has inspired a wide following in athletics and elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: By JERÉ LONGMAN
item.media:credit: Brett Carlsen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mo’ne Davis drew a capacity crowd to the Little League World Series on Wednesday night.

item.title: Women's Wages: How a Part-Time Pay Penalty Hits Working Mothers
item.description: Working fewer than 40 hours per week, as women are likelier than men to do, often results in a lower per-hour wage, furthering the gender gap in pay.
item.dc:creator: By CLAIRE CAIN MILLER
item.media:credit: Yalonda M. James/The Commercial Appeal, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Natalie Vazquez, 27, at a barbecue restaurant in Memphis. Food-service jobs are among the worst in pay disparities for part-time workers.

item.title: Mo’ne Davis, an Ace at the Little League World Series, Proves to Be a Woman Among Boys
item.description: Players in the series range from ages 11 to 13, a time of enormous physical change. But not all change is equal, and girls generally get a two-year head start on their growth spurts.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT CACCIOLA
item.media:credit: Brett Carlsen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mo'ne Davis pitching during her team's 8-1 loss on Wednesday. She struck out six but also gave up six hits and three runs in two and one-third innings.

item.title: Well: Is Breakfast Overrated?
item.description: Researchers are questioning the assumptions behind morning meals.
item.dc:creator: By GRETCHEN REYNOLDS

item.title: Popular and Free, SoundCloud Is Now Ready for Ads
item.description: On Thursday, as part of a new licensing deal with entertainment companies, SoundCloud will begin incorporating advertising and for the first time let artists and record labels collect royalties.
item.dc:creator: By BEN SISARIO
item.media:credit: Jake Naughton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Using the music service on a smartphone.

item.title: Top General Is Named Thai Prime Minister, Sealing Military’s Rule
item.description: Prayuth Chan-ocha, who led the overthrow of Thailand’s government in May, was named prime minister Thursday by a rubber-stamp legislature.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Gen. Prayuth Chan-ocha was chosen as prime minister by the National Legislative Assembly, whose members were handpicked by the junta last month.

item.title: DealBook: $16.65 Billion Mortgage Settlement Nears for Bank of America
item.description: Even as the accord nears completion, prosecutors are preparing a separate civil case against Angelo Mozilo, the man who came to embody the risk-taking for which Bank of America is now paying dearly.
item.dc:creator: By BEN PROTESS, JESSICA SILVER-GREENBERG and MICHAEL CORKERY
item.media:description: Brian T. Moynihan, the chief of Bank of America. He spoke on the phone with Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr.

item.title: DealBook: Texas Car Lender Is Accused of Distortion in Subprime Inquiry
item.description: First Investors Financial Services Group is accused of giving credit reporting agencies flawed data about thousands of car buyers.
item.dc:creator: By JESSICA SILVER-GREENBERG and MICHAEL CORKERY
item.media:description: Richard Cordray, director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, at a House panel last month.

item.title: ISIS Demanded Ransom From U.S. Before Killing Reporter
item.description: The militants had pressed the United States to provide several million dollars for the release of James Foley, an American journalist killed in retaliation for recent airstrikes in Iraq.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.media:description: James Foley in 2012 in Aleppo, Syria.

item.title: What Started as a Local Protest in Missouri Grows Into a Center of National Activism
item.description: Of the 103 people taken into custody during overnight protests on Monday and Tuesday, 23 were from out of state, and the influx has bothered some residents.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL WINES

item.title: Anger, Hurt and Moments of Hope in Ferguson
item.description: Ever since a white police officer fatally shot an unarmed black youth two Saturdays ago, this St. Louis suburb has been deeply troubled.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN ELIGON
item.media:credit: Eric Thayer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters and police officers lined West Florissant Avenue on Tuesday in Ferguson, Mo.

item.title: Brooklyn Man Is Convicted of Making False 911 Calls
item.description: Louis Segna, a 53-year-old resident of the Williamsburg neighborhood, provided myriad details of imaginary incidents like explosions inside a subway tunnel and a person in a van with a pistol.
item.dc:creator: By COLIN MOYNIHAN

item.title: St. Louis County Prosecutor Defends Objectivity
item.description: Citing his past, critics have called for the removal of Robert P. McCulloch, who said he would present the Michael Brown shooting case to a grand jury.
item.dc:creator: By FRANCES ROBLES
item.media:description: A demonstration on Wednesday at the Buzz Westfall Justice Center in Clayton, Mo., where a grand jury will look into the fatal police shooting of Michael Brown.

item.title: TV Habits? Medical History? Tests for Jury Duty Get Personal
item.description: Questionnaires have become increasingly familiar in courtrooms, with some questions covering basic issues and others bordering on the obscure.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHANIE CLIFFORD
item.media:credit: Piotr Redlinski for The New York Times
item.media:description: Roy Futterman, a jury selection expert at Doar Litigation Consulting, says that having charismatic jurors on the client’s side is vital.

item.title: From Missouri to Syria, Journalists Are Becoming Targets
item.description: Reporters, editors and those who monitor the freedom of the press describe a harsh environment for reporters, in the United States and abroad.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By RAVI SOMAIYA and CHRISTINE HAUGHNEY
